Effect of template concentration and crystallization time on catalyst properties and activity Alireza Lotfollahzade Moghaddam Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a Mohammad Ghavipour Writing – review & editing Validation Methodology Investigation Data curation b Jan Kopyscinski Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization b Melanie Jane Hazlett a ⁎ a Concordia University, Montreal H4B 1R6, Canada Concordia University Montreal H4B 1R6 Canada Concordia University, Montreal, H4B 1R6, Canada b Department of Chemical Engineering, McGill University, 3610 University Street, Montreal, Quebec H3A 0C5, Canada Department of Chemical Engineering, McGill University 3610 University Street Montreal Quebec H3A 0C5 Canada Department of Chemical Engineering, McGill University, 3610 University Street, Montreal, Quebec H3A 0C5, Canada ⁎ Corresponding author. The transition to renewable energy from fossil fuels in the transportation industry is crucial for the environment. Dimethyl ether (DME) is a promising substitute for fossil fuels as it can be produced from green hydrogen and CO2 from direct air capture, and in addition has reduced CO, SO x , and NO x emissions upon combustion. This study investigated KFI-type zeolites as catalysts for methanol dehydration to DME while comparing ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 as benchmarks. The influence of template (18-Crown-6) concentration and hydrothermal crystallization time were examined on catalyst properties using characterization techniques including XRD, SEM, BET, DRIFTS, NH3-TPD, and TGA. Activity and stability tests revealed that an optimum KFI zeolite, synthesized with a molar Si/Template ratio of 10:1 and 7 days of crystallization, has superior performance compared to traditional catalysts. The catalyst achieved thermodynamic equilibrium conversion at approximately 185 ℃ (91%) due to high acidity (2466 μmol g–1) and maintained activity for > 100 h. The stable and superior activity is attributed to mesoporous structure and numerous weak acid sites. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords KFI zeolite DME Methanol dehydration ZSM-5 Renewable fuels Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In response to growing concerns about air pollution, global warming, and other environmental issues, scientists are exploring effective solutions for society to maintain their standards of modern living without harming the environment. Substituting fossil fuels with renewable fuels is an effective way to alleviate air pollution problems [1]. Over the last decades, dimethyl ether (DME) has gained considerable attention for its potential energy applications [2], due to its favourable physicochemical characteristics. Particularly, DME has a high cetane number (55−60), high oxygen content (34.8 wt%), no C–C bond, and low emissions of carbon monoxide (CO) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) during combustion [3,4]. DME is compatible with current infrastructures used for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and diesel fuels, which is an advantage over other possible renewable fuels. DME can be directly produced from CO/CO2/H2 or through an indirect process, with methanol as an intermediate or feedstock, respectively (reactions Rx 1 −4) [5,6]. To produce DME, it is possible to utilize CO/CO2 mixture obtained through biomass or waste gasification or CO2 capture making it an environmentally friendly and sustainable fuel [7,8], particularly when green hydrogen from electrolysis is used. Both direct and indirect processes require a solid acid catalyst to facilitate the methanol dehydration reaction. Although γ-Al2O3 has been the conventional solid acid catalyst for methanol dehydration at industrial scale, it has two major drawbacks: (1) it requires high temperatures to reach equilibrium conversion, and (2) it is prone to poisoning by strong water adsorption due to its hydrophilicity [9,10]. Huber et al. demonstrated that Lewis acid sites adsorb water stronger than Brønsted acid sites (for example, by 57 kJ mol–1 for H-SSZ-13) [11]. This explains why alumina, containing Lewis acid sites, is susceptible to water poisoning, which is generated via reactions 2–4. (Rx 1) CO + 2 H 2 ↔ CH 3 OH , ∆ H 298 = − 90.7 kJ / mol , ∆ G 298 = − 25.4 kJ / mol (Rx 2) CO 2 + 3 H 2 ↔ CH 3 OH + H 2 O , ∆ H 298 = − 49.5 kJ / mol , ∆ G 298 = + 3.3 kJ / mol (Rx 3) H 2 + CO 2 ↔ H 2 O + CO , ∆ H 298 = + 41.2 kJ / mol , ∆ G 298 = + 28.7 kJ / mol (Rx 4) 2 C H 3 O H ↔ C H 3 O C H 3 + H 2 O , Δ H 298 = − 23.4 k J / m o l , Δ G 298 = − 16.3 k J / m o l Due to the mentioned drawbacks of γ-Al2O3, alternative catalysts such as heteropoly acids (HPA) and zeolites have found their way into this process during the last two decades since they possess higher acidic strength and are made up of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. Even though HPAs have strong Brønsted acid sites, which is desirable for methanol dehydration, their low surface area (<10 m2 g–1) is a critical barrier to their application at industrial scale [12]. Zeolites have a wide range of structures and porosities, high surface area, Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, and chemical and thermal resistance, allowing them to be widely used in numerous applications, and specifically as catalysts for fuel production [13,14]. The ZSM-5 zeolite is the most common zeolite type used for DME production and has shown superior activity compared to the γ-Al2O3 at low temperatures (< 250 ℃) [15]. On the other hand, certain zeolites can be highly acidic, which results in the formation of coke and byproducts, leading to catalyst deactivation [16]. For example, Migliori et al. investigated the catalytic activity of MOR, FER, and MFI zeolites and found that the MOR sample, with the highest acidity (1034 μmol g–1) exhibited excellent conversion (∼87% at 220 ℃) initially, followed by an intense activity drop within 5 h [17]. Similarly, Y zeolites with a high acidity of 2150 μmol g–1 demonstrated poor stability of less than 10 h in methanol conversion [18]. Another study by Catizzone et al. compared the coke deposition and deactivation rates of Beta zeolite (Beta), MFI, and FER, revealing that Beta showed the highest coke deposition (>60 mgcoke gcatalyst –1) and rapid deactivation [19]. Therefore, it can be asserted that, while acidity plays a crucial role in methanol dehydration, it needs to be carefully balanced with other catalyst properties, such as surface area, crystallinity, and porosity to achieve optimal activity. The zeolite crystal size can have a significant impact on the catalyst performance. Research conducted by Rownaghi et al. evaluated three crystal sizes for ZSM-5 zeolites, 1.2, 0.3, and 0.12 µm, and the results indicated that smaller crystal sizes facilitated the methanol conversion process [20]. Even though all three catalysts had similar total acid density, the nanosized catalyst (0.12 µm) showed 19% higher methanol conversion with a 16% improvement in DME selectivity compared to the larger micro-sized 1.2 µm catalyst. A similar trend was reported for FER-type zeolites, where catalysts with two different particle sizes of (0.3–0.5 µm) and (5–10 µm) illustrated methanol conversion of ∼87% and ∼73% at 220 ℃, respectively [21]. The pore size is an important factor as well, zeolites mainly consist of a microporous structure, however mesopores can be introduced by applying certain synthesis techniques. Alkali treatment (desilication) by NaOH solution, followed by reactivation through ion-exchanged to NH4 + form, has been widely investigated to create mesopores and improve catalytic activity and stability for the methanol dehydration to DME and olefin processes [22,23]. By enhancing diffusion through catalyst grains, mesoporosity can reduce byproduct formation and improve accessibility to active sites. Rutkowska et al. performed alkali treatment on ZSM-5 zeolites for 1, 2, and 4 h, and observed that the ZSM-5 zeolite treated for 2 h achieved 83% conversion compared with 49% over the unmodified sample [24]. Similarly, Aloise et al. demonstrated that a 1 h alkaline treatment on ZSM-5 significantly increased its mesopore volume from 0.089 cm3 g–1 to 0.185 cm3 g–1 [25]. This structure modification enhanced the methanol conversion at 200 ℃ from 75% to 83%, while maintaining DME selectivity, for 80 h. However, high temperatures (>225 ℃) were still required to achieve equilibrium conversion even over the modified ZSM-5 catalysts. The framework structure is also important for initial activity, selectivity, and the stability of the catalyst. Catizzone et al. studied two zeolites with a 3-D framework, including Beta and MFI, and a 2-D zeolite, FER-type [19]. In the case of Beta and MFI zeolites, equilibrium conversion was reached at 260 ℃ and 270 ℃, respectively, while for FER, temperatures over 300 ℃ were required for achieving the thermodynamically-limited conversion. On the other hand, the 2-D FER zeolite, despite its lower activity, showed 100% DME selectivity at high temperatures (300 ℃) and exhibited longer stability (> 44 h, ∼13 h, and ∼6 h for FER, MFI, and Beta, respectively). It was corresponded to the pore and channel size of their structure (channels size: Beta > MFI > FER). Therefore, both pore connection structure and size are critical in catalyst performance. In another study, the fast deactivation of SAPO-34 and EU-1 zeolite was explained by large cages of chabazite with narrow openings and the presence of side-pockets in the channel structure, respectively [26,27]. Generally, the 2-D structures and 3-D framework with small channel size can reduce coke deposition rate[28]. Recent studies have placed emphasis on synthesizing zeolites with tailored properties to enable the equilibrium conversion of methanol at lower temperatures while maintaining high DME selectivity. For instance, Masih et al. assessed the performance of KFI and RHO zeolites for methanol dehydration at temperatures ranging from 150 – 200 ℃ [29]. The RHO and KFI zeolites both showed the equilibrium methanol conversion at 200 ℃ and maintained the activity for 25 h at a low weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 1 h−1. Aside from that, there is evidence to suggest that different preparation parameters, such as the type and amount of template (structure directing agent) and crystallization time, have substantial impacts on the chemical and physical properties of the synthesized zeolite [30,31]. In this experimental work, the performance of the lab-prepared KFI zeolites with a Si/Al ratio of ∼4.3 (5 for the initial gel), as well as two commercial ZSM-5 zeolites with Si/Al ratios of 15 and 25, and a commercial γ-Al2O3 catalyst were studied for DME production via methanol dehydration, employing a WHSV of 4 h–1 which is 4 times higher than a previous study on KFI zeolite. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first investigation conducted on studying the effect of the template amount and hydrothermal crystallization time on KFI zeolite performance for DME formation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The commercial ZSM-5 zeolite (in NH4 +-form) with SiAl = 15 (referred to as MFI-15, Clariant Co.), the commercial ZSM-5 (in NH4 +-form) with SiAl = 25 (denoted as MFI-25, Alfa Aesar), and the γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar) were employed as reference catalysts for DME production to benchmark against the synthesized KFI catalysts. All synthesized KFI catalysts were prepared with SiAl = 5. The KFI zeolites were prepared using a hydrothermal crystallization process based on a previously reported procedure [32]. The materials used in this study for the synthesis and activation of zeolites included potassium hydroxide (KOH, 85%, ACP chemicals), aluminum hydroxide (Al(OH)3, extra pure, Thermo Scientific), 1,4,7,10,13,16-hexaoxacyclooctadecane (organic template, 18-Crown-6 (C2H4O)6, 99%, Thermo Scientific), strontium chloride hexahydrate (SrCl2·6 H2O, 99%, Alfa Aesar), colloidal silica (SiO2, 40 w% solutions in water, LUDOX AS-40, Sigma Aldrich), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 97%, ACP chemicals), and ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, 99.5%, Sigma Aldrich). Initially, three KFI catalysts were synthesized with different Si/Template molar ratios including 10:1, 10:0.5, and 10:0, using a 5-day hydrothermal crystallization. In the next step, to assess the effect of hydrothermal time, the selected catalyst from the first round of experiments (with optimum template content with respect to high catalytic activity) was reproduced under 3, 5, and 7 days of hydrothermal processing time. For the synthesis of KFI (SiAl = 5) with a Si/Template ratio of 10:1, solution A was prepared by mixing 1.00 g of KOH, 2.33 g of deionized water, and 0.52 g of Al(OH)3 powder. Once Al(OH)3 was added, the temperature was raised to the mixture boiling point until a clear solution was obtained. The solution was then cooled, weighed to correct for the weight loss, and mixed with solution B which contained 0.90 g of template (18-C-6;18-Crown-6), 0.09 g of SrCl2·6 H2O, and 3.97 g of deionized water. Next, 5 g of silica source was added dropwise to the combined solution while stirring. After 30 min of stirring, the final gel with a composition of 2.3 K2O:1.0Al2O3:0.1SrO:1.0(18-C-6):10SiO2:160 H2O was transferred into a PTFE-lined stainless steel hydrothermal reactor (Parr Instruments acid digestion vessel, 45 mL), and subjected to crystallization under autogenous pressure at 150 ℃ for 5 days. The resulting mixture was then filtered and washed until the filtrate reached a neutral pH. The collected solid was dried overnight at 60 ℃ and calcined at 600 ℃ for 3 h to remove 18-C-6 from the structure. The same procedure was followed with half the amount of 18-C-6 to synthesize KFI zeolites with a Si/Template ratio of 10:0.5. A slightly different method was employed to synthesize template-free crystallized KFI zeolites. Solution A was similar to the previous method and contained deionized water, KOH, and Al(OH)3. In a separate beaker, solution B was prepared by dissolving SrCl2·6 H2O in water, followed by the dropwise addition of LUDOX AS-40 under vigorous stirring. The two solutions were then combined in a PTFE beaker, resulting in a mixture with the composition of 2.3 K2O:1.0Al2O3:0.1SrO:10SiO2:160 H2O. The mixture underwent hydrothermal crystallization for 5 days at 150 ℃. The remaining preparation steps were the same as the previously-mentioned method. To obtain the H-form of KFI zeolites, which is active for methanol dehydration, an ion-exchanging step was performed with an NH4Cl solution. The process was completed in 3 cycles while in each step 1 g of zeolites were mixed into 100 mL of 1 M NH4Cl solution and stirred for 1.5 h at 80 ℃, followed by filtration and washing with deionized water. Finally, the calcination at 600 ℃ for 5 h was carried out for all samples (KFI and MFI) to change NH4-type to H-type zeolites. The obtained zeolites were labeled as KFI-XTY where X = 1, 0.5, 0 shows the amount of template is the Si/Template molar ratio, and Y = 3, 5, 7 indicates the hydrothermal processing duration in days. For example, KFI-1T3 refers to a sample with initial gel composition containing Si/Template ratio of 10:1 with 3 days of crystallization under hydrothermal condition. 2.2 Characterization To evaluate if the crystallization process was completed during zeolites preparation, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using Rigaku SmartLab SE X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα at 40 kV and 44 mA. The pattern was collected in the 2θ range between 5ᵒ and 80ᵒ while the scanning rate was 5ᵒ min−1. In order to study the textural properties including specific surface area and total volumes of micropores and mesopores, the N2 adsorption/desorption was conducted by 3FLEX Surface Characterization (ATS Scientific Inc.) automated gas adsorption system at − 196 ℃. Before starting the analysis, samples were degassed with Ar for 12 h at 150 ℃. The pore size distribution was determined via the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model using the desorption data, whereas the pore volume was determined based on the amount of adsorbed N2 at p/p o = 0.99. The total Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area was calculated based on the measurements in the relative pressure range of p/p o = 0.03 – 0.3, whereas the t-plot analysis was performed in the range of p/p o = 0.06 – 0.70. The reported standard error of ± 2 m2 g−1 was calculated based on standard deviation divided by square root of sample size after performing three BET tests on KFI-1T7. To measure the samples’ acidity, temperature program desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was performed on an Altamira AMI-300 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Samples were also degassed under pure He (99.999%, Linde) flow for 120 min at 300 ℃ before accomplishing the analysis. The samples were saturated at 60 ℃ with 10 vol% NH3 in balance He (Linde), then were purged with pure He for 60 min to remove the physically adsorbed NH3. Finally, the desorption was conducted by increasing the temperature with a 5 ℃ min–1 rate and the ammonia desorption profile was recorded at 60 − 550 ℃ under the constant flow of He (10 mL min–1). To study the surface morphology of catalysts and determine the particle size distribution, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out using a S-3400 N HITACHI equipment at 15 kV. To prepare samples for SEM, catalysts were mounted on an aluminum slab and gold was sputter-coated on the samples. The average particle size was estimated by analyzing a SEM image containing 50 − 55 individual particles. Also, the Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) was performed to measure the Si/Al ratio in synthesized and commercial zeolites. Coke deposition on the spent samples was measured by performing temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) in a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, Netzsch TG 209 F1). The spent samples (for 100 h reaction) were loaded in an alumina crucible and heated from 25 ℃ to 900 ℃ with a ramp rate of 5 ℃ min–1 under 30 mL min–1 flow of synthetic air, while the weight change was recorded. To distinguish the weight reductions due to either moisture removal or coke combustion, the temperature was maintained at 200 ℃ and 600 ℃ for 0.5 h, respectively. The water content of the catalysts, determined by weight loss at temperatures ≤ 200 ℃, was utilized to adjust the sample mass and present coke formation rate derived from the dried catalyst weight. To evaluate the coke composition deposited on various zeolite types, the following procedure was employed: 20 mg of spent catalyst (40 mg in case of KFI zeolite) was digested with 5 mL of a 4 M KOH solution. Subsequently, 5 mL of dichloromethane was added to the solution to extract the hydrocarbons from the aqueous phase. The resulting solution comprising coke was then analyzed using a GC-MS (Agilent Technologies) instrument in a temperature range of 50 – 300 ℃, with a solvent delay of 3 min. The column used was an Agilent HP5-MS UI, with dimensions 30 m x 0.250 mm ID x 0.25 µm film thickness. To understand the nature of the acid sites, diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were carried out. The sample was first dried at 300 ℃ for 120 min under a N2 (99.999%, Linde) stream, and after cooling to room temperature, a N2 gas flow containing 10 vol% of acetonitrile-d3 (CD3CN) was passed through the dried sample. This process continued for 2 h to complete the saturation. Finally, the saturated sample was purged with pure N2 flow for 2 h to desorb unstable acetonitrile-d3 molecules, and the DRIFTS analysis was performed using a Nicolet™ iS50 FTIR instrument equipped with an MCT detector. The spectra were recorded in the 600 − 4000 cm−1 wavenumber range with an optical resolution of 4 cm−1 at 50 ℃. 2.3 Catalytic activity The catalyst performance for DME production was investigated using a vertical fixed-bed quartz reactor within specified temperature ranges under atmospheric pressure inside an electric furnace. For the zeolite samples, the temperatures ranged from 130 ℃ to 220 ℃, while for γ-Al2O3, the temperature range extended from 130 ℃ to 310 ℃. A calibrated gas chromatograph (GC, SRI) equipped with an FID detector, with a HP-PLOT Q column (30 m length, 0.32 mm ID), was used to measure both the feed and output gas concentrations from the reactor. To prevent methanol condensation, the gaseous stream was heated to 120 ℃ between the mass flow controller, reactor, and the GC analyzer. For each experiment, 100 mg of catalyst was placed into the reactor. Prior to the reaction, pretreatment procedures were implemented. For γ-Al2O3, the catalyst was pretreated at 400 ℃ for 1 h, while for zeolites, pretreatment was conducted at 500 ℃, both under a pure Ar (99.999%, Linde) flow rate of 20 mL min–1. After pretreatment, the reactor was cooled down to 125 ℃, and the gas flow was switched to a mixture of methanol (CH3OH) and Ar. The liquid methanol was injected into the heated lines (at 120 ℃) by a syringe pump, mixing with the Ar flow (as an inert gas) to achieve a gas composition containing 30 vol% methanol. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 4 gMeOH gCat –1 h–1, corresponding to a 22 mL min–1 total flow. Data was collected under steady-state conditions (every 30 min for 3 h at each temperature setpoint). The ramp rate to each setpoint was 2 ℃ min–1. In order to check the reproducibility, the activity tests were replicated for some of the samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The XRD patterns of synthesized KFI zeolites are shown in Fig. 1. The major diffraction pattern peaks were observed at 2θ = 9.6°, 20.2°, 21.3°, 29.5°, and 31.9°, which were also observed for activated catalysts indicating no structural changes (Fig. S1). However, the sample without template was less stable during the activation process, as depicted in Fig. S1. These peaks are associated with crystal phases of well-prepared KFI zeolites and in agreement with literature [33]. The effect of the template on the crystallization of catalysts was obvious by comparing the KFI-1T5, KF-0.5T5, and KFI-0T5, where the synthesized zeolite without template had lower crystallinity (as evidenced by broader peaks with lower intensities) than the other two (Fig. 1d and e). The influence of the crystallization degree on the catalyst activity will be described in the activity section. The most crystalline samples were achieved by Si/Template = 10 with a 5- and 7-day hydrothermal crystallization. The SEM images, presented in Fig. 2, show the synthesized KFI zeolites have a cube-like morphology, and the ZSM-5 zeolites are spherical. Also, they confirmed the results obtained from XRD analysis which show the successful crystallization process for all the samples except for the sample without any template (Fig. 2e, KFI-0T5). Based on the SEM images, the average particle sizes of zeolites were estimated at 1.5 − 1.8 µm for KFI-1T5, 2 µm for KFI-0.5T5, and 2.4 µm for KFI-0T5, indicating that the usage of higher amount of template can result in smaller particles. The crystal size of 7.7 µm and 0.38 µm were measured for MFI-15 and MFI-25. The distribution of crystal size for different catalysts has been presented in the Supplementary Information (Fig. S2 − S8). Fig. S9 and Fig. S10 show the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the prepared catalysts with the focus on the influence of template concentration and crystallization time. The adsorption isotherm of the KFI-1T7 is a combination of the type I and type IV IUPAC classifications, where mesopores are associated with type IV and micropores by type I [35]. Mesopores were also observed in KFI-1T5 and KFI-0.5T5 but fewer than observed in KFI-1T7. This shows that both longer crystallization and higher template consumption within the ranges that have been tested can promote the existence of mesopores in the zeolite structure. The specific surface area and pore volumes of samples, along with other properties, are reported in Table 1. The EDS analysis demonstrated that the final obtained catalysts had a Si/Al molar ratio of 4.3, while the value for the initial gel was 5. However, it validates our preparation method compared to previous studies which reached Si/Al of 3.3 with the same starting gel composition [29]. A direct correlation was found between surface area and the amount of template or crystallization time. Therefore, the highest surface area of 541 ± 2 m2 g−1 was measured for KFI-1T7. Regarding the ZSM-5 zeolites, a higher BET surface area was observed for MFI-25 (360 m2 g−1) compared to MFI-15 (233 m2 g−1), which can be related to the particle size difference in these samples. While the total specific surface area increased with more template and longer crystallization for KFI samples, there is not a clear trend observed for the micropore and mesopore surface areas. The templated samples had a high BET surface area (> 390 m2 g−1), whereas the untemplated KFI-0T5 possessed a low surface of 205 m2 g−1, indicating the importance of a template for KFI-type zeolite synthesis. From the untemplated (KFI-0T5) to using half the template concentration (KFI-0.5T5), the micropore surface area increased by 228 m2 g−1 and the mesopore surface area increased by 31 m2 g−1. From using half the template concentration (KFI-0.5T5) to the full template concentration (KFI-1T5), a more modest increase in micropore surface area (51 m2 g−1) and mesopore surface area (14 m2 g−1) was observed. From 3 days to 5 days of crystallization, there is a significant increase in micropore surface area (143 m2 g−1) but a slight decrease in mesopore surface area (24 m2 g−1). From 5 to 7 days of crystallization, the micropore surface area is unchanged and the mesopore surface area increased (28 m2 g−1). The NH3-TPD profiles are presented in Fig. 3, and the quantitative results for weak and moderate/strong acid sites were summarized in Table 2. NH3 will desorb at different temperatures depending on the strength of the acid sites, particularly NH3 desorbs from weak acid sites in the range of 150 – 250 ℃, medium acid sites 250 – 350 ℃, and strong acid sites 350 – 550 ℃ [36]. Fig. 3 indicates two major peaks at temperatures around 166 − 194 ℃ and 391 − 452 ℃, which are associated with weak and strong acid sites, respectively. Comparing the two MFI samples (Fig. 3a and b), MFI-25 has fewer acid sites compared to MFI-15, which can be attributed to its higher Si/Al ratio. Due to the negative charge caused by Al3+ in the zeolite structure, which facilitates the presence of H+, replacing Si4+ with trivalent cations (Al3+) at lower Si/Al ratios leads to the generation of Brønsted acid sites [37]. The KFI zeolites have a greater number of acid sites, ranging between 343 and 844 μmol g–1 more than MFI-15, demonstrating their potential for increased activity. The weak/strong acidic sites ratio was also calculated to relate acid sites strength to the catalytic performance. Notably, the temperatures corresponding to the recorded peaks (T weak and T strong) in KFI-1T7 were higher than those observed in other synthesized samples, indicating that the acid sites are stronger. According to Table 2, higher template usage in the catalyst gel preparation resulted in higher acidity. The presence of template may affect the distribution and position of Al in the structure which changes the acid density [37,38]. It can improve acid site accessibility and increase the strength of acid sites with undetectable acidity. Data showed that by incorporating the template (KFI-0T5 → KFI-0.5T5), weak acid sites increased sharply while strong acid sites did not change much. In contrast, higher amounts of the template (KFI-0.5T5 → KFI-1T5) only strengthened the available sites and the total acidity did not change significantly. 3.2 Catalytic Activity 3.2.1 The effect of template concentration Fig. 4a presents the steady-state methanol conversion obtained using KFI zeolites with varying template quantities used along with comparison to γ-Al2O3 as the commonly employed catalysts in the industry. The investigation covered a temperature range from 130 ℃ to 220 ℃, allowing for a comprehensive understanding of catalytic behavior. Also, Fig. S11 shows the methanol conversion over two different KFI samples with Si/Template ratio of 10:1 under 5 days of crystallization to confirm the reproducibility of synthesis method and activity experiments. A methanol conversion of less than 10% was observed for all samples at 130 ℃. As the temperature increased, there was a positive impact on methanol conversion. As a comparison, zeolite samples achieved 4.3 − 6.6 times more conversion than γ-Al2O3 at 190 ℃. Even at the highest temperature (220 ℃), the conversion over the alumina catalyst reached approximately 40%. This lower performance can be attributed to the weak acidity of alumina, possessing solely Lewis acid sites while zeolites contain both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [39]. In previous studies, FTIR spectroscopy analysis suggested that water adsorption on Lewis acid sites, such as those present on γ-Al2O3, is stronger than on Brønsted ones [40]. This implies significant competition between water and methanol molecules for adsorption on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface. This competition becomes critical in methanol dehydration since equal moles of water and DME are produced during methanol dehydration (see reaction Rx 4). This justifies the higher activity of KFI samples relative to γ-Al2O3. Accordingly, even the least active zeolite, KFI-0T5, exhibited a conversion of 59% at a low temperature of 190 ℃, which is higher than the conversion recorded over alumina. The lowest activation energy of 80.5 ± 0.4 kJ mol−1 (Fig. 4b) calculated for γ-Al2O3, using the Arrhenius equation (Eq. 1), shows that this catalyst is less temperature-sensitive than others. As a result, higher temperatures will be required to achieve a higher conversion rate. (1) ln rate = ln k − E R 1 T Analysis of the conversion, as reported in Table S1, revealed a specific catalytic activity order: KFI-1T5 > KFI-0.5T5 > KFI-0T5, which aligned with the surface area and number of acid sites order of these zeolite samples. The KFI-1T5 had 2.3 times higher conversion than KFI-0T5 at 180 ℃. The results showed an inverse correlation between crystal size and catalytic activity, where catalysts with smaller particles had higher activity, consistent with previous investigations [41]. These findings suggest that the utilization of templates in the synthesis of KFI zeolites has a beneficial effect on the degree of crystallinity, surface area, acid sites, and crystal size, ultimately improving methanol conversion efficiency. The results are in line with previous studies, which have shown that the type and template concentration in the synthesis solution have profound effects on the final zeolite activity for different types of zeolites [42,43]. The activation energies reported in Fig. 4b show that KFI-1T5 is the most sensitive to temperature, thus conversion increases faster with temperature. A direct correlation was found between these catalysts’ acidity and activation energies which is in line with previous studies [44]. The analysis of the gas exited the reactor demonstrated remarkable 100% selectivity towards DME over all the zeolite samples at temperature > 160 ℃ (Fig. S12 − S17). At low temperatures, traces of butene and pentene were detected as byproducts. However, with increasing temperature, the DME selectivity increased in gas phase and no byproducts were detected. This high selectivity signifies the potential of KFI zeolites as efficient catalysts for DME production through methanol dehydration by reducing the costs of the following separation units. The catalytic activity in Fig. 4a, combined with the insights from the literature, emphasizes the significant impact of catalyst selection on methanol conversion efficiency. Zeolites, particularly the KFI variants, outperformed the alumina catalyst due to their higher acidity and unique properties, such high surface area. The use of templates in the synthesis of KFI zeolites further enhanced their catalytic activity by improving crystallinity, surface area, and crystal size. These findings contribute to the advancement of sustainable energy solutions by promoting the utilization of efficient catalysts in DME production from renewable sources. 3.2.2 The effect of hydrothermal processing duration Among the KFI zeolites samples with different template quantities, KFI-1T5 demonstrated superior methanol dehydration activity. To further investigate the influence of crystallization time on the catalytic activity of KFI-type zeolites, additional tests were conducted at the same temperature range for zeolites with varying crystallization time from 3 to 5, and 7 days. Fig. 5a also shows the methanol conversion over the KFI synthesized catalysts as well as the commercial ZSM-5 zeolites (MFI-15 and MFI-25) for comparison. Over the MFI-15 zeolite, the methanol conversion reached equilibrium at 210 − 220 ℃, exhibiting superior conversion compared to previous studies involving this type of zeolite [17,24,25,28]. This is related to various initial gel compositions and preparation parameters followed in papers and by the suppliers of MFI zeolites in this study. For example, Migliori et al. prepared a gel with a Si/Al ratio of 25 (resulting in a final Si/Al ratio of 34) which exhibited 439 μmol g−1 total acidity [17]. The catalyst required temperatures > 240 ℃ for equilibrium conversion at WHSV of 4 h−1 (80% conversion at 240 ℃). In another study, Rutkowska et al. utilized a commercial ZSM-5 zeolite with Si/Al ratio of 16.5 (close to the ratio in this study) and achieved equilibrium conversion of 85% at 275 ℃ for WHSV of 0.5 h−1 [24]. The lower activity observed in their catalyst is attributed to its highly microporous structure (91% of surface area related to microporosity)[24], whereas in this study, the catalyst has 76.4% of surface area related to microporosity due to different preparation factors employed by the manufacturers. Similarly, the enhanced performance of the MFI-15 sample compared to MFI-25 can be attributed to higher acidity (1942 μmol g−1 and 1308 μmol g−1, respectively) stemming from its lower Si/Al ratio, as observed in the literature [45]. KFI zeolite samples with different crystallization times exhibited a shift in the conversion curve towards lower temperatures, indicating their increased activity in methanol dehydration while maintaining 100% selectivity for DME. KFI zeolites demonstrated at least 2.14 and 1.46 times higher DME yield than MFI-25 and MFI-15 at 170 ℃, respectively. The activity results revealed the following order: KFI-1T7 > KFI-1T5 > KFI-1T3, highlighting the significant influence of hydrothermal processing time on the structure, surface area, and activity of the prepared zeolites. In this regard, the sample prepared using the full template concentration and 7 days of crystallization achieved an equilibrium conversion of ∼91% at 185 ℃. This catalytic activity is notable compared to the methanol conversion at 220 ℃ of other zeolite types including FER (85%) [17], MOR (88%) [17], desilicated ZSM-5 (86%) [25], Y (∼83%) [24], Beta (75%) [28], SAPO-34 (81%) [46], EU-1 (60%) [28], ZSM-22 (44%) [47], ZSM-12 (30%) [47] under reaction conditions reported in Table 3. Although, Catizzone et al. [21] and Rutkowska et al. [23] improved the FER and ZSM-5 catalysts by modifying crystal size and mesoporosity, the conversion of around 87% could not be reached at temperatures below 220 ℃. Other solid acid catalysts reported the methanol conversion at 250 ℃ such as AlPO4 (80%), aluminum hexagonal mesoporous silica (Al-HMS) (70%), Al-MCM-41 (58%), and 10% Ag/η-Al2O3 (40%), under reaction conditions given in Table 3 [48–51]. Since the activity improvement was less pronounced when increasing the crystallization time from 5 to 7 days than 3 to 5 days, a sample with longer crystallization time was not investigated. Furthermore, an increase in acidity was observed when the synthesis time was extended from 3 to 5 days whereas, a reverse trend was recorded when the crystallization time increased from 5 days to 7 days. Al is surrounded by 4 Si, but the second layer of neighboring atoms can differ the acidity of the proton attached to the bridging oxygen. The higher the electronegativity of the neighbouring atoms, the higher the acidity of the proton attached to the central tetrahedra. Si has higher electronegativity compared to Al. Hence, the proton attached to Al (4Si)(8Si) has higher acidity than Al (4Si)(8Al) [52]. Longer hydrothermal may lead to higher Al incorporation into the zeolite structure. So, Al incorporation to a certain point increases the acidity and from a certain threshold decreases the acidity. This could be why 5 days of hydrothermal crystallization yielded the most acidic catalyst and the longer hydrothermal diminished the acidity of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 5b, highest activation energies of 104.5 ± 4.5 and 102.1 ± 3.5 kJ mol−1 were observed for KFI-1T5 and KFI-1T7, respectively, indicating that conversion would accelerate quicker at low temperatures with these two catalysts than with other. However, there is no direct correlation between activation energies and acidity among these samples. It demonstrates that other factors such as zeolite type, surface area, and crystallinity can be critical as well as acidity. Achieving the highest specific surface area with 7 days of crystallization, the higher degree of crystallinity, the formation of mesopores, and a optimum W/S (W/S = weak/strong) acid sites ratio improved the zeolite's performance in methanol dehydration reaction. Mesoporosity creation through alkaline treatment and its beneficial effect on DME production have been studied extensively in previous projects [53,54]. This mesoporosity enhances the accessibility of active sites for methanol molecules and facilitates the diffusion of coke precursors, thereby preventing active area loss. This could explain why the more mesoporous sample with the higher crystallization time possessed a superior performance. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that achieving an optimum value for the W/S acid ratio is crucial. Excessively high W/S ratio values can result in less active catalysts at low temperatures. Conversely, excessively low ratios can lead to rapid deactivation due to the susceptibility of strong acid sites to coke deposition. The recorded values of around 1.85 for KFI-1T7 appear to be the optimal ratio in this context. To compare the catalytic activity of the acid sites in different zeolites, the turnover frequency was calculated at 130 − 170 ℃ using Eq. 2, where n ̇ M e O H , XMeOH , AStotal , and mcat represent the molar flow rate of methanol (mol h−1), conversion (dimensionless), total acid sites (mol g−1), and the catalyst weight, respectively. The results were shown in Fig. 6, confirming the higher activity of acid sites presented in KFI-1T7. KFI-1T7 with the highest TOF of 41.8 h−1 provided 1.26 times higher TOF than ZSM-5 zeolites. Therefore, the type of zeolite and the preparation factors can have an important effect on the methanol dehydration. (2) TOF = n ̇ MeOH X MeOH AS total m cat Overall, the investigation of crystallization time and its impact on KFI zeolite catalytic activity revealed the importance of both structural characteristics and mesoporous formation in determining methanol conversion efficiency. The findings align with previous studies emphasizing the role of porosity in enhancing methanol dehydration and DME production. It is also worth investigating the nature of acid sites on different zeolites. The most active KFI sample, KFI-1T7, was selected to compare to the reference zeolites. Fig. 7 shows the DRIFTS spectra and deconvolution of peaks corresponding to different acid sites at 50 ℃. The wavenumber range of 2240–2340 cm−1 is evaluated, which corresponds to the vibration of CN bonds in acetonitrile to acid sites of the zeolites. According to Pelmenschikov et al., [55] this area reveals five distinct peaks at 2278 cm−1, 2284 cm−1, 2300 cm−1, 2323 cm−1, and 2332 cm−1, which are associated with CN bonds to terminal Si-OH, nonacidic sites, bridging OH groups, weak Lewis acid sites, and strong acid sites, respectively. Applying this definition to the observed results in this study, the Lewis/Brønsted ratio was 0.39, 0.33, and 0.13 for KFI-1T7, MFI-15, and MFI-25, respectively, which is inversely proportional to the Si/Al ratio of zeolites as expected [37]. The presence of a huge band at 2278 cm−1 for KFI-1T7 represents the importance of CN bonds with SiOH groups while the previous papers focused on the band at 2300 cm−1 [25]. Therefore, the KFI zeolite possessed weaker acid sites which can influence the stability of the catalyst. 3.2.3 Stability tests Commercialized DME production through a catalytic process requires a catalyst that exhibits high activity and selectivity thereby reducing the cost of subsequent process separation steps for the reactor's output gas. In the previous section, the KFI-1T7 catalyst met these requirements. However, catalyst stability is another critical factor in evaluating a catalyst for industrial-scale applications, as it directly impacts the need for reactor shutdowns or switching to replace or regenerate the catalyst, thereby affecting overall process economy. For instance, certain highly acidic catalysts, such as HPAs (heteropoly acids), exhibit strong acidity and suitable activity at low temperatures but suffer from rapid deactivation within a few hours of operation (∼4 h) [56,57]. To assess catalyst stability, the selected KFI-1T7 catalyst and the two commercial ZSM-5 samples were subjected to a 100 h stability test (the results presented in Fig. 8). It was found that MFI-15 and MFI-25 maintained high conversion rates for 20 and 60 h of operation, respectively. This deactivation is attributed to the loss of active sites caused by coke formation and particle agglomeration. The SEM images of the fresh and used ZSM-5 catalysts indicate some agglomeration, shown in Fig. S19. In contrast, the methanol conversion over the synthesized KFI-type zeolite remained stable for over 100 h. In previous studies, hierarchically-structured ZSM-5, Al-HMS, 10% Ag/η-Al2O3, FER, and MOR zeolite types exhibited 25 h, 10 h, 60 h, 60 h, and 5 h stability, demonstrating the superior performance of the prepared KFI in the present study [17,24,28,50,51]. The consistent methanol conversion rate for 100 h indicates a low rate of coke formation, and can be related to the DRIFTS and NH3-TPD results. The presence of weak Brønsted acid sites and higher amount of weak acid sites (1601 μmol g–1 for KFI-1T7 compared to 1168 μmol g–1 for MFI-15) reduce the production of heavy hydrocarbon and increase the catalyst lifetime. The SEM images of fresh and used catalysts (Fig. S19) revealed the structural stability of the KFI catalyst under the process conditions. The total coke formation on each catalyst was measured by TGA and reported in Fig. 9. The measured coke formation was 0.33 mgcoke gdry-cat −1 h−1, 0.25 mgcoke gdry-cat −1 h−1, and 0.20 mgcoke gdry-cat −1 h−1 for MFI-15, MFI-25, and KFI-1T7, respectively. The measured coke formation rate for KFI is also lower than previously reported values over other zeolites, FER (0.75 mgcoke gcat −1 h−1), MOR (1.2 mgcoke gcat −1 h−1), ZSM-5 (1.0 mgcoke gcat −1 h−1), EU-1 (1.5 mgcoke gcat −1 h−1), ZSM-22 (0.51 mgcoke gcat −1 h−1), Beta (1.31 mgcoke gcat −1 h−1), and SAPO-34 (2.5 mgcoke gcat −1 h−1) [17,28]. The total coke formation of 20 mg gdry_cat –1 over 100 h was achieved using KFI zeolites, while Migliori et al. [17] and [28] reported the lowest coke formation of 45 mg gdry_cat –1 and 31 mg gdry_cat –1 over 60 h using FER and ZSM-22, respectively. Maintaining the temperature at 200 ℃ facilitated the drying of the catalysts, and the weight loss observed between 200 ℃ and 600 ℃ was attributed to the amount of coke deposited on the catalysts. Two factors can explain the long lifetime of KFI catalyst: First, the lowest coke deposit value measured on KFI-1T7 revealed its exceptional selectivity toward DME. Second, a optimum Weak/Strong (W/S) ratio aided the KFI sample in retaining its catalytic activity even with coke deposition. Another reason for low coke formation is the lower equilibrium conversion temperature on KFI compared to catalysts studied in literature. It may be that the activation energy for successive dehydration of DME to hydrocarbons and coke precursors is not supplied at this low temperature resulting in diminished coke formation. With further analysis of the coke species formed over deactivated catalysts, we aimed to uncover the coke formation mechanism and justify the behavior of the catalysts within the stability tests. The results of the coke analysis conducted by GC-MS were presented in Fig. 10. It is important to highlight that digestion using 4 M KOH and extraction with DCM were completed, as no insoluble compounds were observed. For ZSM-5 zeolites with 10-member ring channels, two aromatic compounds, namely pentamethyl benzene and hexamethyl benzene, were detected, which is consistent with the literature [41]. In contrast, the 8-member ring of KFI zeolite led to the production of linear and lighter coke species, such as 2,6-dimethyl nonane (C11H24) and 1,3-bis(1,1-dimethylethyl) benzene (C14H22). Using Eq. 3, the coke selectivity was estimated based on the results of coke deposition on the catalyst by TGA analysis and the composition of coke determined by GC-MS (the results are presented in Table 4). In Eq. 3, N MeOH→Coke , n ˙ M e O H , XMeOH, and t represent methanol converted to coke based on the TGA result (mol), methanol flow (mol h−1), conversion (dimensionless), and total time (100 h). The KFI-1T7 catalyst exhibited the lowest selectivity of 0.011% for coke generation. (3) S coke = N MeOH → Coke n ˙ MeOH X MeOH t + N MeO H → Coke It is speculated that the presence of a mesoporous morphology in KFI zeolite played a dual role: first, enhancing activity by providing more accessible active sites, and second, increasing stability by preventing heavy coke deposition and pore blockage. The remarkable activity and stability results highlight the substantial potential of the synthesized KFI zeolite for cost-effective DME production. This zeolite is cost effective as it last for long time while maintaining excellent activity and selectivity for DME synthesis [58]. 4 Conclusions This paper investigates DME production through methanol dehydration, utilizing synthesized KFI-type zeolites in comparison to the commercial ZSM-5, and γ-Al2O3 catalysts as benchmarks. Five KFI zeolites were prepared by varying the template usage in the synthesis (zero, half, full) and crystallization time (3, 5, 7 days). XRD, SEM, and BET analyses revealed the significance of the template in transforming the initial gel into zeolite with high crystallinity and surface area. Moreover, N2 adsorption/desorption profiles indicated that a crystallization time of 7 days played a crucial role in creating a mesoporous structure. The optimal sample (KFI-1T7) exhibited remarkable 2466 μmol g−1 of acid sites and a favorable weak/strong acid site ratio of 1.85. Activity tests were conducted at temperatures ranging from 130 ℃ to 220 ℃, using a WHSV of 4 h−1 and a feed containing 30% methanol. The conversion-temperature relationship demonstrated that zeolite with a full template and 7 days of crystallization exhibited improved methanol conversion, reaching equilibrium conversion at approximately 185 ℃. Furthermore, the stability of the most active KFI zeolite was compared to the commercial ZSM-5 zeolites over a 100 h methanol dehydration reaction. The synthesized KFI-1T7 zeolite displayed stable activity over 100 h, while the two commercial catalysts lasted for 25 and 60 h. TGA indicated the lowest coke formation rate (0.20 mgcoke gcat −1 h−1) for KFI-1T7 compared to other catalysts. Also, the highest TOF of 41.8 h−1 and lowest selectivity to coke (0.011%) was calculated for optimum KFI. Coke analysis indicated that the smaller channel size of KFI than ZSM-5 zeolites led to coke species with smaller kinetic diameters. These findings demonstrate the importance of template amount and crystallization time in synthesizing KFI zeolites with enhanced activity, stability, and lower coke formation. The KFI-1T7 zeolite showed significant potential for DME production, outperforming commercial catalysts be demonstrating high activity at low temperatures, long stability, and low coke formation rate. coredata.dc:description: The transition to renewable energy from fossil fuels in the transportation industry is crucial for the environment. Dimethyl ether (DME) is a promising substitute for fossil fuels as it can be produced from green hydrogen and CO2 from direct air capture, and in addition has reduced CO, SO x , and NO x emissions upon combustion. This study investigated KFI-type zeolites as catalysts for methanol dehydration to DME while comparing ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 as benchmarks. The influence of template (18-Crown-6) concentration and hydrothermal crystallization time were examined on catalyst properties using characterization techniques including XRD, SEM, BET, DRIFTS, NH3-TPD, and TGA. Activity and stability tests revealed that an optimum KFI zeolite, synthesized with a molar Si/Template ratio of 10:1 and 7 days of crystallization, has superior performance compared to traditional catalysts. The catalyst achieved thermodynamic equilibrium conversion at approximately 185 ℃ (91%) due to high acidity (2466 μmol g–1) and maintained activity for > 100 h. The stable and superior activity is attributed to mesoporous structure and numerous weak acid sites.
